item.title: The Rain In Spain Stays Mainly In The Plain
item.author: Jaqueline Steiger
item.description:
Or, how phonetics works.

When I was in undergrad, I was one of those obnoxious students that fell in love with IPA, the international phonetics alphabet. My best friend (who also had 9am Monday/Wednesday phonetics classes and was the same kind of nerd as me) and I would pass notes in IPA in class. Not for any reason. Just for funsies. Surprisingly, we also both got laid in college.

To be fair, it is a really cool system. The way that IPA works is that each SOUND has exactly one symbol that describes it. And no, that’s not how any “regular” alphabet works. English is especially terrible for that. What sound does a c make? What about an a? Or even better, the Chomskiest of all Linguistics jokes.

“How do you spell fish?”

“ghoti - gh ais in laugh, o as in women, and ti as in function.”

ba-dum-tis (cymbal noise)

So what IPA does is allow you a system to transcribe the exact SOUNDS of anything.

It’s precise, it’s gorgeous, you can be as broad or as nitpicky with your transcriptions as you like, and it is 100% logical. I was hooked. I wanted to teach THE WHOLE WORLD IPA. My friend and did actually do a thesis where we taught IPA to ESL students in a classroom and see how their pronunciation skills improved. It was insane.

Eventually I grew up and realized that it’s not always feasible to teach language-learners an entirely new alphabet AS WELL as an entirely new language. But if you’re a language nerd, a pronunciation fanatic, want to know what dictionary pronunciation is, or you are trying to learn an accent it is a priceless tool.

I use IPA a lot in this blog, but generally in the broader sense. a word bounded by slashes - /slash/ is phonemic transcription - the most generally recognized way to transcribe. It doesn’t bother with diacritics like aspiration, dental or apical co-articulation, or releases. That’s phonetic transcription, and it’s generally marked by [brackets].

I at some point will probably talk about all the cool shit hidden in IPA and phonetics, like syllabified m and n, the ridiculous amount of fricatives hiding in English, and the sounds that we DON’T have in the English language. Maybe I’ll also tell the story of how I cockblocked some guy with linguistics knowledge LIKE A BOSS.

Right now, we’re focusing on IPA and English phonetics in general though.

How Kind Of You To Let Me Come

English is generally divided into consonants and vowels. We have around ten vowels, and around 21 consonants. This is a subject of huge debate among phoneticists though. is the sound a “w” makes a consonant, a glide, or a vowel? I DONT CARE IT’S NEAT.

Consonants are classified by the place of articulation in the mouth, the manner of airflow constriction, and voicing.

Vowels are classified along four axis of front/back, high/low, round/unround and a mystery axis tense/lax.

Here are some normal words written in IPA. Primary stress is marked with a superscript tick-mark ‘ and secondary stress (if it exists) is marked with a subscript tick-mark ˌ.

/əˈlon/

/ɪmˈpɹɛ-ʃɪn/

/ˈlɛk-ʃəɹ/

/rəˈpli:t/

/ˌsʌ-pləˈmɛn-tʃɹi/

/ˈlæpˌtɑp/

/ædˈmɪ-ʃən/

/ˈlæɾ-ɪˌtu:d/

/əˌlɑŋˈsaɪd/

/ˌɛ-pəˈlɛp-tɪk/

Now I’m going to do some weird trivia.

With Blackest Moss The Flowerpots

ch /tʃ/ is realy a fast t - sh sound.

j /dʒ/ is really a fast d - ʒ (that squiggly letter is the ge sound in mirage) sound.

Affricates are neat. They start out as plosives/stops/whatever you want to call them, where the airflow is entirely blocked. And then they really quickly become fricatives - the sounds that you can hum forever.

Moses Supposes Erroneously

We have three nasal sounds in English - those are sounds where air is blown through the nasal cavity as well as the mouth. You can recognize them because they are the sounds it is impossible to say when you have a stuffy nose.

We have a bilabial nasal plosive, /m/.

We have an alveolar nasal plosive, /n/.

And we have a velar nasal plosive /ŋ/.

/ŋ/ is the “ng” sound, and you can remember it because it looks like an “ng” squished together. It’s the sound at the end of “singing”. It is in fact, one sound though. We don’t really notice in English because it cannot occur word-initially so we don’t think about it as a real sound independent of orthography. But LOTS of other languages do have this sound word-initially, and it is one of the first stumbling blocks that English-speakers have when learning phonetics. (Let’s not even get go into the uvular trill or pharyngeal sounds.)

Thankfully, I learned to pronounce this fairly early in undergrad, as it’s a SUPER prominent sound in Thai. It’s the letter ง, and is the first sound in งู /ŋu:/, snake.

Wouldn’t It Be Loverly

As continuing evidence for my obsession with the phonetic alphabet, my web dev friend and I are making you an app so that you too can type in IPA whenever the mood strikes you. We will shortly have available an IPA keyboard compatible with iphone and ipad for all of your transcription, secret-note-passing, accent-learning, or language-teaching needs.

item.author: Jaqueline Steiger
item.description:
Are apparently a huge deal and in one of the sections of the DELTA. Unfortunately, there are NONE in the assigned reading for the task I’m working on. Do I draw these assumptions from other readings in this week? From the course material? From THE FUCKING AIR?

Now I’m looking at old tests (they do release them, neat) and blogs from other people who have taken the DELTA. I’m going to start listing some assumptions.

  2. Collaboration/pairwork
  3. Visuals

  7. Integrated focus on skills
  8. Variety
  9. Textuality
  10. Process modeling

man, I don’t know. I’m going to have to come back to these assumptions, they’re apparently extremely important.

item.title: Adjacency Pairs, We Meet Again
item.author: Jaqueline Steiger
item.description:
My undergrad Linguistics & Anthropology degree was heavily influenced by ethnomethodologists, both in linguistic anthropology and conversational analysis. Some of my professors were pioneers in the field of discourse analysis, and we had to do a LOT of ethnomethodological study. This involved giving waivers to all my friends and carrying a tape recorder around for awhile, as there’s no perfect way to amass a lot of real-world conversational data.

One of the most important (or prominent) types of utterances in dicourse is the adjacency pair. This is a standardized two-part utterance that almost everyone recognizes the pattern of. Here are some examples:

greeting - greeting

congratulations - thanks

apology - acceptance

inform - acknowledge

leave-taking - leave-taking

Like, ALL CUSTOMER SERVICE INTERACTIONS*

Can you think of real-world examples of all these? I bet you can.

Further Adjaceny Pair Nonsense

According to my book,

“The mutual dependence of [adjacency pair] utterances is underlined by the fact that we can only be absolutely sure of the function of the initiating utternace when it is contextualized with the response it gets, and vice versa.”

*fun fact we did conversational analysis of sleepy college students ordering Jamba Juice in the school cafeteria and customer service interactions are basically MODEL ENVIRONMENTS to find and study adjaceny pairs.

Jamba Employee: “Good morning, welcome to Jamba Juice!”

Hungover Student: “Hi.”

JE: “What can I get for you?”

HS: “Can I have a small Razzmatazz with vitamin boost?”

JE: “Anything else?”

HS: “No, that’s it.”

JE: “That’ll be $4.50.”

HS: “Here you go.”

JE: “Thanks, have a nice day!”

HS: “Thank you.”

Can you spot all the adjaceny pairs? Sometimes gestures or grunts were substituted for an utterance, but the function was the same.

Robot Code and Fluency

Native speakers tend to seem more free with their speech patterns than non-native speakers do. That’s not really true, native speakers just have more options and knowledge about what CAN plug into each speech pattern.

“This is not to deny the usefulness of formulae as a survival kit at the most elementary levels, nor should we forget that muc native-speaker language is formulaic; it is simply that the native speaker usually has a vastly greater range of formulae to call upon for use in a wider range of strategic domains, along with a flexible and adaptable lexicon of non-formula based items.”

Basically, native speakers are working with more complex code.

item.title: Vocabulary and Text Organizing
item.author: Jaqueline Steiger
item.description:
More Classifications of Words to Talk About Words

My book is talking about “closed systems” versus “open systems” in lexis. There are words which are grammar words and words that are lexical words.

Grammar words: and, to, the, in, this…

Lexical words: monkey, sculpture, temperance, aboriginal…

And then it turns out there’s also a secret class of words called discourse-organizing words. These are words like issue, problem, assessment that help us frame how we think about the discourse AROUND them.

They’re both super useful and pose problems for language learners. A student who has trouble with discourse-organizing words may be disadvantaged in the struggle to decode whole texts as efficiently or accurately as possible.

Modality Is Also Cool

Modality is usually thought to be the province of modal verbs such as can, should, might etc. But actually, based on the research, a lot more lexical items are used to express modality:

Apparently, assume, doubt, guess, as if, suggest, think, actually, surprisingly

All these words help us ascertain the attitude of the speaker/writer. While the actual modal auxiliary verbs are fairly frequently taught in classrooms, the REST of the words expressing modality are given far less time and attention.

Innnnnnteresting.

item.title: Lexical Cohesion is Sick
item.author: Jaqueline Steiger
item.description:
So we know about synonyms and antonyms and hyponyms and all that shit, right? Turns out its not just trivia questions for English teachers and people who like to analyze poetry.

We USE all those things in everyday speech, CONSTANTLY.

“How was the party last night? Fun?”

“Oh man, it was off the hook! Everyone was wasted.”

“Aw, jealous. I haven’t been proper tanked in awhile.”

Fun and off the hook are synonyms. Wasted and tanked are synonyms. We use reiteration and collocation constantly in order to link feelings and concepts in speech, and in order to keep topics moving.

A small number of lexical chains can account for almost all of the content items IN a conversation.

More Usefulness

Data shows (and anecdotal evidence would support) that English speakers don’t respond to every utterance with “I agree” or “I disagree”. We use lexical cohesive devices to state our agreement or disagreement without sounding like insane robots.

Instantial relations are discourse-specific lexical relations. If normally “cute” is a desirable trait, but in a specific dialogue it is framed as an undesirable trait, “cute” and “awful” and synomyms for bad things would be considered as having an instantial relationship.

item.title: Study Cheatss
item.author: Jaqueline Steiger
item.description:
A Few Cheat Sheet Notes

These have come up in discussion questions, and I feel like I should probably remember them.

Same Same But Different Words

homonyms - same spelling, same sound, different meaning e.g. like as a verb, like as a preposition homographs - same spelling, different sound, different meaning “Do you like to read?” “I read the book yesterday.” homophones - same sound, different spelling, different meaning “I ate eight pieces of pizza.”

Lexis Nonsense

Lexical set - car, bus, train etc (words that belong to the same group e.g. vehicles) Lexical field - bus, conductor, driver (words that belong to the same topic)

Interlanguge

Interlanguage is the type of language produced by second- and foreign-language learners who are in the process of learning a language. In language learning, learner’s errors are caused by several different processes. These include: 

a. borrowing patterns from the mother tongue  b. extending patterns from the target language.  c. Expr

item.title: Types of Grammatical Cohesion
item.author: Jaqueline Steiger
item.description:
In discourse analysis, the current boring thing I’m reading about, grammatical cohesion and textuality are super important.

Textuality is basically the idea that utterances or discourse can be studied as a whole - as a text - as opposed to a series of sentences. Not super sure why it needed its own word for that, it seems like a tautology to me. Pieces of text can and should be analyzed as text. The book is even more vague about it.

“textuality, that is, the feeling that something is a text, and not just a random collection of sentences.”

Cool. Thanks, I guess. Textuality is more of a feeling than a helpful definition.

Cohesion and grammatical cohesion are easier to understand for me.

“The grammar of English offers a limited set of options for creating surface links between clauses and sentences of a text. Basically, most texts display links from sentence to sentence.”

Essentially, a text wouldn’t go “I went to the park to see the squirrels. An alien took over the city.” and then continue on about the park/squirrel story without addressing the alien story.

There’s a few (three-ish) helper concepts in the support of grammatical cohesion.

Reference

Reference items include pronouns, articles, and demonstratives, as well as a few weird preposition-type-dudes. References point from one part of a text to another.

“The schoolhouse had a red roof with a small chimney. It was cold in the summer and hot in the winter.”

It obviously applies to the schoolhouse, linking the two sentences together. Looking backwards in the text like that is called anaphoric reference.

References to assumed, shared worlds outside the text are exophoric references. These references will be shared by the speaker and audience, and are generally part of cultural awareness or the zeitgeist. “Things in the US are tense, until the election”. If the audience is reading the sentence in the time it’s written, they probably wouldn’t ask “which election?”

References that point to parts of the text we haven’t experienced yet are called cataphoric references. These often involve pronouns but can also involved definite articles.

Ellipsis

Ellipsis is a weird word. Also, Ellipsis is the omission of elements normally required by the grammar which the speaker/writer assumes are obvious from the context and therefore need not be raised. This isn’t just “everything in a text must be spelled out at all times” - that’s unnatural speech and how you know someone is an alien and/or robot. Specifically, ellipsis is distinguished by the structure of the discourse having some missing elements.

“The children will carry the small boxes, the adults the large ones”.

“will carry” is omitted in the second clause because it can be assumed from the first clause.

There are three kinds of ellipsis in English, nominal, clausal, and verbal, referring to what is being omitted.

We care about ellipsis because

it creates difficulties in learning. Not only in learning what structural omissions are permissible, but also it doesn’t seem to be readily used even by proficient learners in situations where native speakers naturally resort to it.

Weird.

Substitution is also similar to ellipsis, but it’s the use of new words instead of just omitting. “Do you want a chocolate?” “Just one.” “Who likes pizza rolls?” “I do!”

This kind of shit is not easily and directly transferrable to another language, so it’s weirdly fascinating to me.

Conjunction

Is apparently cheating to include during our talk of grammatical cohesion? I don’t know why the book needs to tell me this. A conjunction does not set off a search backward or forward for its referent, but it does presuppose a textual sequence, and signals a relationship between segments of the discourse.

These can be the literal conjunction parts of speech, a metatextual phrase (on the other hand), or a lexical item somewhere else in the clause.

Some nerd has categorized conjunctions into elaboration, extension and enhancement.

item.title: What Is Discourse, Though?
item.author: Jaqueline Steiger
item.description:
Discourse is a fancy-ass word that relates to speech acts and the study of ELT. It doesn’t have a really good definition but lets go over its key elements.

  1. It occurs in a context - language is typically embedded in real life settings, as opposed to artificial or produced sentences. We are involved in a myriad of speech acts every day, and the only false ones seem to be texts that are created specifically for learning. Weird, right?
  2. It involves above-sentence level of analysis - when loking at discourse, we are dealing with whole stretches of spoken or written text, rather than single sentences. Rarely in real-word contexts do we look at a single sentence - even if we do, it is placed in a larger environment (car prices, the relationship between the speakers, etc).
  3. It involves meaningful language - Language needs a context to give it meaning (yup, we established that). Meaning usually springs from the context in which discourse is used, with the status and/or roles of the speakers, the intentions of those involved in the communication being decisive in determining the form of the discourse which arises. Not entirely sure how this is different from context, tbh. Similar to the necessity of purpose, I guess.
  4. It always involves imperfect language - Error and imperfection are an inevitable result of any human behavior. Real language is not a matter of producing perfect sentences - discourses can be fragmentary, elliptical, and difficult to understand if the context is not clear. This is a HUGE difference with model texts - how many errors are present in every-day speech while it remains salient? How artificial does “perfect” speech sound?
  5. It usually involves some sort of communication - (durrr) Even if it is a single sentence, again, a meaning was conferred. Generally, discourse is language used for communication.
  6. Spoken discourse involves utterances rather than sentences - this is mostly a semantics-based point. Spoken pieces of dialogue are called “utterances” rather than sentences because they may not be grammatically perfect enough to count as sentences, because they may overlap, or because they are more informal.

item.title: 3 Models of ELT
item.author: Jaqueline Steiger
item.description:
This Is Boring But I Have To Know It

And now you will too.

There seems to be a “natural order” of grammatical morpheme acquisition, and it goes as follows:

-ing (progressive) (noun) plural(s) copula (‘to be’) ↓ auxiliary (progressive as in He is going) article ↓ irregular past ↓ regular past –ed third person –s possessive ’s

Which is actually pretty neat. And there seems to be some evidence of regression - once a student has internalized a rule and goes on to do something else, they might synthesize that old rule incorrectly.

Here are three conflicting theories about language learning:

Behaviourism

With the British “u” and everything. This is based on modeling and imitation, and requires positive reinforcement and corrective strategies. Based off behavioural psychology, which was essentially a “pics or it didn’t happen” branch of psych.

This branch of learning stresses listening, repetition, imitation, and correction, as well as the acquisition of generative structures in a linear fashion.

Obviously the backlash to this produced:

The Innatist Perspective

Dammit, Noam. Stay out of this. So this one is the idea of the Universal Grammar and Generative Grammar and a lot of Noam Nonsense. It’s got good points, in that babies can’t have heard every speech utterance. There has to be SOME sort of internal language system.

Neither of these two systems are perfect, though.

Side Note for Krashen

Krashen is the guy the The Lexical Approach author has a huge hard-on for. He suggests:

“there was an essential difference between learning and acquisition, the former being akin to the conscious learning one does in class, the latter being largely unconscious and at a deeper, more permanent level. It also proposed that acquired language gave rise to spontaneous production (fluency), whereas learned language would be more deliberate, consciously produced, probably for a pedagogical or other formal purpose (accuracy).

A related hypothesis proposed that learners used a monitor to check what the accuracy and appropriateness of what they were saying, sometimes consciously, often unconsciously.”

He also had the idea of the affective filter, the novel concept that things that are engaging and low-stress are easier to learn. Shocking.

Now that we’re in the 21st century and everything has to be goddamn interdisciplinary all the time, we’re moving towards many

Cognitive Perspectives

There’s Information Processing Theory, “the idea of cognitive effort, which in turn involves attention, processing and automatisation”.

There’s Declarative and Proceduarl Learning, concepts that are basically “knowledge that” and “knowledge how”. Thanks, cog sci. This is super groundbreaking.

The Interaction Hypothesis is another one that someone got to claim but is really self-explanatory:

  1. Interactional modification makes input comprehensible 

  2. Comprehensible input promotes acquisition 

  3. Therefore interactional modification promotes acquisition

And then there’s the Sociocultural Approach which says that learning doesn’t happen in a vacuum and prioritizes the social event:

…emphasising the social event rather than the internal goings-on in the mind. Thus, student and tutor, or student and student co-constructed meaning in acting out an interactive event, with the learning arising out of the event itself, and the co-operation between the interactants.

The nature of input was important: it had to be interesting, challenging but not so difficult that it led to frustration. In short, it had to be focused and carefully graded – proximal to the stage of the learner’s stage of development. The theory went that deeper processing occurs when a learner is focused on what they are hearing from their interlocutor and while they are formulating their response. The process of production or output supposedly aids deeper understanding.
